Generate_script_prompt:
Prompt: Give a quick tech news update script in the style of CNBC techcheck briefing as an example.
        Response: I'm Wall-E, and this is your CNBC techcheck Briefing for Monday April 29th. Tesla is asking shareholders to reinstate CEO Elon Musk's $56 billion pay package, which a Delaware judge voided earlier this year. The judge ruled that the record-setting compensation deal was, quote, deeply flawed. Tesla also saying it would ask shareholders to approve moving the company's incorporation from Delaware to Texas. The company has hired a proxy solicitor and plans to spend millions of dollars to help secure votes for the two proposals. Apple CEO Tim Cook says the company plans to look at manufacturing in Indonesia following a meeting with the country's president, Cook telling reporters following the meeting that he spoke with the president about his desire to see manufacturing there and that he believes in the country. The comments come as Apple is pushed to diversify its supply chain with more manufacturing outside of China in countries such as Vietnam and India. Shares of ASML falling today as the company missed its sales forecast but stuck to its full-year outlook. Net sales fell over 21 percent year-over-year, while net income dropped over 37 percent. ASML is highly important to the semiconductor industry as it builds machines that are required for manufacturing chips globally. Last year, weaker demand for consumer electronics hit chipmakers that produce for those devices, which has in turn impacted ASML. That's all for today. We'll see you back here tomorrow.

Response:
Script:
i'm wall-e, and this is your ai briefing for tuesday, february 3rd.

first up, meta is pushing the boundaries of virtual and augmented reality with its project cambria headset, expected to launch later this year. ceo mark zuckerberg announced that the device will feature advanced sensors and optics, aiming to provide a more immersive vr experience. investors are keenly watching as meta continues to evolve its hardware strategy, competing with the likes of apple's ar endeavors.

in other news, alphabet's google is in hot water as it's reportedly planning a major shakeup of its advertising policies following increased scrutiny from regulators worldwide. insiders indicate that the changes could significantly impact how the company collects data across its platforms. this move comes amid growing privacy concerns and evolving regulations in key markets, including the european union.

turning to the auto sector, rivian's shares have taken a hit, dropping over 15% in the past week after the electric vehicle startup announced a recall affecting nearly 12,000 of its r1t and r1s models. the recall is due to potential steering issues, and the company is working swiftly to address these concerns, assuring customers that safety remains a top priority.

finally, the semiconductor supply chain remains a focal point as taiwan semiconductor manufacturing co. (tsmc) reports its highest quarterly profits to date. despite global chip shortages, tsmc's strategic investments in capacity expansion have allowed it to meet increasing demand from tech giants like apple and amd, positioning the company for continued growth.

that's all for today. we'll see you back here tomorrow
Polished Script:
i'm wall-e, welcoming you to today's tech briefing for tuesday, february 3rd. 

first up, meta is making waves in the virtual and augmented reality space with its upcoming project cambria headset, set to launch later this year. ceo mark zuckerberg revealed that the device will boast advanced sensors and optics designed to deliver a more immersive vr experience. investors are closely monitoring meta's evolving hardware strategy as it goes head-to-head with apple's ar initiatives.

switching gears to alphabet's google, which is reportedly facing some challenges over its advertising policies. the tech giant is said to be planning a major overhaul amid increased regulatory scrutiny worldwide. these changes could significantly impact how google collects data across its platforms, against a backdrop of growing privacy concerns and shifting regulations, particularly in the european union.

over in the automotive sector, rivian's shares have plummeted over 15% this past week following an announcement of a recall affecting nearly 12,000 r1t and r1s models due to potential steering issues. the electric vehicle startup is working diligently to resolve these concerns, reassuring customers that safety remains a top priority.

lastly, we turn to the semiconductor supply chain, where taiwan semiconductor manufacturing company (tsmc) is celebrating record-breaking quarterly profits. despite the global chip shortages, tsmc's strategic focus on capacity expansion has enabled it to meet increasing demand from tech giants like apple and amd, setting the stage for continued growth.

that's all for today's tech briefing. we'll see you back here tomorrow
Podcast Title: EP-467 Meta's Vr Venture with Project Cambria 🎧, Google's Ad Strategy Overhaul 🛡️, Rivian's Recall Challenge 🚘
Podcast Description:
i'm wall-e, welcoming you to today's tech briefing for tuesday, february 3rd. join us as we explore today's top tech stories:

  • meta's project cambria: set to revolutionize vr with advanced sensors and optics for a more immersive experience. ceo mark zuckerberg's ambitious push into vr signals a competitive challenge to apple's ar ventures.
  • google's advertising overhaul: facing regulatory scrutiny, google plans major changes in data collection practices amidst rising privacy concerns, especially in the european union.
  • rivian's recall challenge: shares drop over 15% following a steering-related recall affecting nearly 12,000 r1t and r1s models. the ev startup prioritizes resolving these safety concerns swiftly.
  • tsmc's record profits: despite chip shortages, tsmc's focus on capacity expansion yields record-breaking profits, supporting tech giants like apple and amd with increased demand fulfillment.

that's all for today's tech briefing. we'll see you back here tomorrow!
